According to Professor Richard Harding in his book Firearms and Violence in Australian Life, we are well on the way to reaching the American situation. He describes the domestic gun scene in Australia as destructive, volatile, self-perpetuating and intractable.

Our political leaders, when asked to comment on events such as the Reagan assassination attempt, claimed smugly that our laws are much tighter. This may be so, but the eight Australian police commissioners have pointed out that, through a hole in our regulations, the Israeli Uzi machine pistols and the Russian Kalashnikov assault rifles can be imported into this country. This type of weapon is used by terrorists and armed criminals throughout the world and is favoured by private armies in many countries. In the context of the increasing dangers to society from all types of firearms, no tightening of firearms regulations will be too much. We must act to ensure that what has happened in the United States cannot happen here. Uniform and stringent federal regulations on the use and possession of firearms is a vital necessity.

This is a very real problem for the local people and it is causing them very severe stress and costing tens of thousands of dollars as well as devaluing their home investment. Whilst I appreciate the need for the Lysterfield Gun Club and its aims and objectives, it is obviously out of touch with the reality of residential life in my electorate. I suggest that an inquiry into the location and nature of all gun clubs in Australia is necessary to establish more satisfactory zoning and positioning of these ranges and to remove them from proximity to residential areas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like to draw the House's attention to some aspects of the assets test that has been introduced by the Government. I spoke today to a lady whose husband retired in January 1983. She works part time one day a week. Her husband had to retire early due to illness, but they are both on the pension. The amount of her earnings is not sufficient to interfere either with her fringe benefits or the payment of a full pension. Their home is valued at $70,000. They own a rather old panel van, and between them they have been able to save $3,600 over their working lives. Under the proposals for the assets test, the $3,600 is $1,100 over the prescribed amount of $2,500. Ten per cent off that works out roughly to an additional $2 a week income which is not calculated under the present system.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sure that there will be no doubt about this couple receiving fringe benefits, but what I am concerned about under the proposals is whether their pension will be reduced. The lady I spoke to is concerned that her pension may be reduced. She said to me on the telephone: 'We have no jewels, we do not have a boat, we have no antiques; we have our house and our panel van. That is all we own. We have $3,600 in the bank'. From the lump sum she has been able to save she is looking forward to setting aside amounts as gifts for grandchildren, perhaps for a holiday and, eventually, when the time comes-they are very healthy people-they want to pay for their own funerals, as many people in these circumstances do.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I have to take a point of order. The honourable member must know that they can have savings of $17,000 if they are single or $28,000 if they are married. Hasn't that penetrated his skull yet?
—Order! There is no point of order.
—Mr Speaker, it is a spurious point of order. If the Government were to examine the fine print of the decision it has made it would understand why a person in these circumstances is concerned.
—You don't understand it.

—I have not misrepresented anything the Government has proposed. I have read it carefully and I suggest the honourable member do the same. If the Government wants to consider this matter carefully I think it should adopt a different approach than that of throwing wildly into the House something concerning hundreds of thousands of people and their future and then having the matter drag on for 12 months before they know exactly where they stand.

SPEECH.PARA: The lady I spoke to is Mrs Nell Wulff of 413 Stacey Street, Bankstown, which is in the electorate of Blaxland. I suggested to her that she take the matter up with her Federal member, and this she will do.

Another aspect of this tax which will not affect this family is this: Suppose they owned a holiday cottage and decided today to give it to their family as a gift. One thing that people in these circumstances need to know is whether for the next 12 months after the introduction of these measures their pension will be reduced to take account of the asset they held and disposed of after Budget night. Is there to be a retrospective claw-back on pensions because they happen to give away assets to their family as a gift during the next 12 months? That matter needs to be examined. I think it is dreadful that, without proper consideration, the Government brings in measures such as this in a Budget. I also think that the Government ought to consider what would happen if a person had retired and had taken a lump sum payment which would have been taxed at 30 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable gentleman's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Simmons Mr D.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to address some comments tonight to predictability and stability in liquid petroleum gas matters. Earlier today the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) raised some matters relating to liquid petroleum gas. Ten years ago liquid petroleum gas was regarded in the industry as somewhat like sawdust. The New South Wales local government gas industry, an industry that has existed for more than 100 years, converted from coal based gas production to LPG 10 or 15 years ago for a number of reasons. Many people relied on reticulation through the towns and cities which the industry serviced and, because of competition from electricity and heating oil, towns mains that should have been renewed were allowed to fall into disrepair. As a consequence, the obvious solution was to change from reticulated supply to in situ liquid petroleum gas or re-formed LPG through the existing reticulation system. Like many members in this chamber, I represent an electorate that has a significant number of liquid petroleum gas consumers. Some 14,000 such consumers live in the Federal division of Calare. I have always had a great interest in gas matters as an Alderman of the Bathurst City Council. Since 1980 I have served on the New South Wales Local Government Gas Advisory Committee and still occupy the position of Deputy Chairman of that organisation; hence my interest in liquid petroleum gas.

SPEECH.PARA: To give an indication of the changes in prices I will cite examples of price fluctuations in LPG over the last 10 years. The ex-refinery price of liquid petroleum gas in Melbourne in May 1974 was $27.56 per tonne. At the same time naturally occurring LPG was $24 a tonne. There was a steady and predictable increase in the price for the next five years. In January 1979 the price of ex- refinery and naturally occurring LPG was $88 a tonne. However, in the space of 12 months the price trebled, which represented to the Government a 70 per cent increase in duty. The traditional users of liquid petroleum gas mounted an intensive campaign against such a sharp increase in excise. The Fraser Government was forced to introduce a subsidy or, as people in the industry, particularly the traditional users of LPG prefer to call it, an excise rebate of $80 a tonne. Unfortunately, the Government has changed the basis of the collection of excise from an export parity related price to a crude oil indexed price from 1 July this year. The local government gas industry accepts and expects that prices will increase from time to time, but the point is that such increases must be predictable and produce a degree of stability, particularly for local government, because local government budgets on matters such as gas reticulation normally on a 12 months basis. It has a very debilitating effect upon consumers when changes in gas prices take place during a local government financial year.

During the past 10 years LPG prices have increased more than elevenfold. The Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) is reviewing the future of the LPG subsidy prior to 27 March 1984, when the subsidy is due to expire. I urge the Government, in reviewing the future of the subsidy, to bear in mind the stability considerations that I have mentioned. I make these points in view of the fact that most LPG users are country people, most of whom do not have the luxury of natural gas in their area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr I.M.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity to bring up the subject of the new Countrywide Calling program which has been introduced by Telecom Australia. This follows a notice of motion which I put to the House this morning . The Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) supports this new concept in his Press release of 12 August 1983. It involves the rearrangement of the old Liberal-National Party community Access 80 which allowed everyone to call his local business centre for a local call charge, which on 1 October will become 15c. That date is significant to the pricing arrangements, because Telecom will increase its charges on that date following Labor's mini-Budget, which asked Telecom for another $100m in interest payments which it owes the Government. Therefore, the Australian Labor Party has increased telephone charges in Australia. The Countrywide Calling concept is very good for people who live in isolated areas, but if one happens to live outside the 32-kilometre radius from one's exchange, one will pay 5c a minute for a call. Under the old community access operation a person could ring his local business centre for the cost of a local call, which under the old charges was 12c but which under the new charges will be 15c, without any timing.

SPEECH.PARA: Those of us who live outside the 32-kilometre area are being discriminated against by the Labor Party. Not only are people being discriminated against in the charge for local calls, but they will also continue to be discriminated against in the conversion of manual exchanges to subscriber trunk dialling exchanges. The charge for people to convert is presently a maximum of $600 and they are the only Australians who are expected to pay to have their manual exchange converted from manual to automatic. The Minister for Communications claims that, while some people would notice an increase in the cost of a small number of calls from local to community call rates, this would be outweighed by a big reduction in other calls.

I argue that the bulk of calls by most people are made to persons living in the local community. I would like the Minister to look at the charging arrangements that are associated with the Countrywide Calling program. This program was introduced to help the introduction of digital radio concentrators which will be established in the far flung areas of electorates such as Maranoa. They have a radius of 600 kilometres with boosters every 40 kilometres. No doubt the new charging arrangements will be of benefit to people in these areas. However, a large number of rural subscribers who are living in what I call the middle settled areas will have to pay a lot more for their local calls. I believe that it is up to the Minister to look at this problem and see whether it can be rectified. If anybody makes a call beyond 64 kilometres he will have to pay on a time basis. This is the first time that such an imposition on country people has been introduced. I am still one of those people who believe that we ought to be able to contact our nearest centre of business for a local call charge, because our cousins in city Australia are able to do exactly that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLeay Mr L.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take a few moments to comment on the rather cowardly attack that was made on me earlier this evening by the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Fisher). I understand the honourable member for Mallee suggested that I should reply to some remarks that he made. It would have made it a lot easier if the honourable member for Mallee had had the courtesy of most other honourable members in this House and advised me that he was going to make the critical remarks he did.
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. I informed the honourable member yesterday that I would be endeavouring to reply-
—Bloody liar!
—to his ill-founded comments either yesterday or today.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—I raise a point of order, Mr Speaker. The honourable member just said-it was clearly heard-the words 'bloody liar'. Those words should be withdrawn. They reflect on the honourable member for Mallee and they are not true.
—I did not hear the words. I ask the honourable member if he used the words to withdraw them, but if he denies using them I cannot enforce it.
—Mr Speaker, it is a fact that the honourable member for Mallee never informed me that he was going to make this scandalous attack tonight.
—Mr Speaker-

—Order! The honourable member for Denison will resume his seat. I inform the honourable member for Grayndler that the honourable member for Denison has said that he used certain unparliamentary terms. I replied that I did not hear them, but if the honourable member did use them he should withdraw them as they are now recorded in Hansard. If he used those words I ask him to withdraw them.

—Mr Speaker, I will withdraw them. In continuation of my remarks, I find it rather interesting that the honourable member for Mallee never found the term offensive. However I think the honourable member for Mallee should be aware that the courtesies normally followed in this House are that one advises a person if one is going to make an attack on him.
—I raise a point of order. Mr Speaker, I informed the honorable member yesterday.
—Order!
—I met him in the corridor and told him.

—Order! I warn the honourable member for Mallee. I remind honourable members that they may not take frivolous points of order. The honourable member was making a personal explanation; he was not taking a point of order. The honourable member for Mallee has done it twice. I call the honourable member for Grayndler.

—Mr Speaker, what the honourable member has been doing, as you have quite rightly said, has been frivolous. The remarks he made earlier this evening were even worse than frivolous. The honourable member for Mallee is not telling this House the whole truth. The honourable member alleges that he has had many letters and many telephone calls. Let him table in this House all these letters he has received. He might have one or two letters from some disaffected people.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us recall what I said last week in the criticisms I made about some sports funding in this country. I said that the problem with sports funding in this country was the parlous position we had been put in by the previous Liberal Government because of its heartfelt guilt of the way it dealt with the Australian athletes who attempted to participate in the Moscow Olympics. Because of the heartfelt guilt of the previous Prime Minister and his sycophants on that side of the House, the previous Government set up the Australian Institute of Sport so that members of the Government could say that they were trying to do something for sport. It never occurred to them at any time before that that they should do anything about sport, but all of a sudden they got this great idea to try to get themselves off the hook with the Australian people. The previous Government forgot about sports development; it forgot about the little people who play sport; and it forgot about the State champions, unlike my predecessor, the Hon. Frank Stewart who was a Minister for Sport in the previous Labor Government. He did a lot of work for sports people in this country. Malcolm Fraser and his cohorts forgot all about them.

Let us look at the record of the previous Labor Government, the previous Liberal Government and the great sport Budget that has been brought down in this Parliament in the last couple of days. I will not be stood over by the opportunists on the Opposition side to be uncritical of anything. I will be critical of the Institute of Sport or any other organisation that I feel, as a member of parliament, I should be critical of. I would like to see the remarks I made taken in context rather than taken out of context for cheap political shots by cheap politicians on the Opposition side of the House. Mr Speaker, I can assure the House, as you are aware, that I will conduct the inquiry being undertaken by my House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure with the impartiality that that inquiry deserves. It is a pity, however, that members of the Opposition cannot find themselves something more interesting to prattle on about in this House. Nothing they have said has assisted sport; nothing they did in the past assisted sport; and all they are trying to do now is knock to get themselves a very cheap headline.

TALK.START.PARA: —I reply tonight to what I believe to be one of the most dishonest speeches we have heard in this House for a while. It was delivered by the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) a little earlier this evening when he was talking about the assets for pensioners test. The honourable member might have the brain of a peewee, but I thought he would have been able to work out the simple arithmetic that accompanys the assets test. He knows as well as I do that the person he spoke of is covered completely and would receive a full pension and full benefits. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said yesterday that a single person can in fact--
—You are wrong again.

—I am telling the honourable member the facts now. After having a house, car, boat, caravan and all personal belongings such as furniture and the first $1,500 cash exempted from the assets test, a single person can then have $ 17,100 in the bank or in another place. For a couple, it is $28,500. This has been worked out, even for the honourable member, very simply. The amount of $17, 100 minus the $1,500 exemption equals $15,600. The assessable income which is assessed at 10 per cent is $1,560 which is 30 times 52. But what is the honourable member saying? The honourable member for Mallee (Mr Fisher) came into the House and said that the person he spoke about had $3,600 in the bank and was frightened. The honourable member was not denying the fact that he said pensioners would probably have a cut in their pension. The honourable member and his friends are going to move around this country and deliberately distort the facts which the Prime Minister alluded to yesterday. The honourable member is distorting the facts and he knows as well as I do that the vast majority of pensioners in this country will not be affected by the assets test. In fact, some people will even be better off.
—Rubbish!

—The honourable member for Denison interrupts, but he knows as well as I do that I am telling the truth. The Opposition is distorting the facts and the honourable member for Denison will obviously distort the facts in his electorate in Hobart. The facts are--
—I raise a point of order, Mr Speaker. I do not know whether the honourable member implies that I was distorting the facts. I suggest that he read my speech very carefully tomorrow.
—Order! That is not a point of order. The honourable member will resume his seat. I call the honourable member for Isaacs.

—The Government has brought in the assets test because of the economic bankruptcy it found this country in. The stupid decision made by the previous Government in 1976 meant that many thousands of people-they were nearly millionaires in some cases-gained pensions. This Government has announced the assets test. It has also announced that it will not apply until approximately 12 months after the introduction and passing of the legislation. The Prime Minister and the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) have said in a number of Press releases over the last 24 hours that the Government will be talking to pensioner groups and veterans groups in the next few months in order to get ideas from them. The honourable member for Mitchell knows as well as I do that if any anomalies come up-I have one which I have not time to go into; I have already made representations to the Minister for Social Security-the Government will take all those into consideration. The honourable member should be trying to pacify pensioners and should be telling them the facts of the matter so that when the legislation is brought before this House it is fair to everyone in this country and will be a better system, a fairer system and a more equitable system for all the elderly people in this country.
—I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes, I have been misrepresented on two counts.
—The honourable member may proceed.
—First of all, I met the honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Leo McLeay) in the corridors of the place yesterday. I informed him that I would be raising this-
—You said that you were going to give me a bashing in the House later in the week.

—I thank the honourable member for admitting it. Secondly, I have been misrepresented in the fact that the honourable member for Grayndler said that we did nothing for sports development programs. My Government introduced the sports development program and funded 76 national bodies.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member has permission to make a personal explanation, not to debate the matter. He should not abuse an indulgence given to him by the Chair.
